awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: New Methods for Spatial Analysis of Electoral Districts
awd_abstract_narration:
The doctoral dissertation research project will develop a new general method to measure the impact individual districts have on estimates of advantage associated with different configurations of legislative units.  The doctoral student will empirically examine the relationship between existing indicators of district boundary configuration and new measures that he will develop and test.  He will evaluate the fundamental assumptions common in the analysis of electoral advantage, and he will assess the validity of different measures as well as fundamental statistical assumptions in electoral modeling techniques in order to determine the robustness of estimates to spatial dependence.  This project will expand basic understanding of electoral dynamics.  It will improve the accuracy, fidelity, and usefulness of electoral models, and it will provide new tools for analyzing legislative district plans, thereby contributing to societal debates about the configuration of electoral unit boundaries.  The simulation techniques developed in this project also will be applicable for sensitivity analysis of other kinds of spatial models.  As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

The doctoral student undertaking this project will extend existing symmetry measures to examine individual district contributions to the estimated asymmetry of a redistricting plan.  These new local measures of district influence will be used to analyze the impact strangely shaped districts have on a plan's overall estimated advantage for one group over others.  Two fundamental components of electoral models will be assessed.  The student will interview redistricting officials and stakeholders to guide and inform the development of new measures of electoral advantage in order to ensure they are meaningful and useful in practice.  He also will evaluate the impact of geospatial dependence in estimating the relationship between the share of seats a group wins in a legislature and the share of votes the group receives across all districts.  He will assess legislative election models for potential spatial misspecification, and he will assess the degree to which an increase in aggregate support for a political group is modeled by a set of independent, randomly distributed district changes.  The student also will examine the spatial structure of electoral swings to improve the models on which the new local influence measures depend
.

por.por_cntn:
The dissertation funded by NSF#1657689, Spatializing Partisan Gerrymandering Forensics: Methods & Measures, examined partisan bias, electoral geography, and the conceptual basis for measures of partisan bias. The dissertation, defended in December of 2017 (due for publican in winter of 2019) involved four distinct projects:

  • Data: Development of an open replicable geographical dataset about elections in US Congressional Constituencies
  • Post-Hoc Analysis: Analysis of models used to assess partisan bias in electoral districting plans. 
  • Shape & Local Bias: Analysis of the correspondence between measures of geographical "regularity" for congressional districts & the individual district contribution to electoral bias
  • Validity Study: Interviews to assess the construct validity & practical applicability of measures of partisan bias. 

Below, the project results will be discussed in turn.

Data

Using two existing datasets and a significant amount of cleaning, linking, and processing, a new data product, outlined in Wolf (2017) was developed. Further, Wolf (2017) examines basic validation and comparison of the new dataset to an existing & longstanding dataset, ICPSR 6311. Finally, Wolf (2017) makes public the entire chain of processing required to obtain the final data product; the entire process is repeatable when the input data changes or is updated. This update has already been run twice to incorporate the 2016 & 2018 election results. More generally, this project makes a high-quality geographical dataset public, free for use, and ensures that the dataset is both maintainable and replicable. 

Post-Hoc Analysis

In this phase of the project, basic assumptions in models of partisan bias were analyzed. The study found that many assumptions about how vote shares tend to change and vary over space and time were found to be unrealistic. This means that changes in vote shares from year to year were found to be geographically clustered, rather than independent from place to place. Nearby congressional districts tend to drift together, towards or away from one party or another (regardless of whether the districts are drawn to be safely for one party or the other). Even though this was not often accounted for in the literature, its introduction did not improve models. This is important: while the typical model of the electorate may appear to be overly simplistic from a geographical perspective, the introduction of spatial or geographic information did not significantly change results.

Shape & Local Bias

One way individuals feel they can identify gerrymandering is to look at the shape of a district itself. If the district looks odd, then it is likely gerrymandered. However, this misses the mark. Oddly shaped districts can  act either in favor of and against the party that wins the district. Finally, it can also be the case that geographical features, like mountain ranges, rivers, or coastlines, require unnatural shapes to represent nearby inhabitants. Taking four existing measures of statewide partisan bias, this project developed local sensitivity measures to model the impact each district has on statewide partisan bias. Impact scores measure how strongly each individual district contributes to overall bias. Using impact scores, the project found no significant association between partisan impact on bias and geographical regularity. Thus, it is unlikely that shape and bias have a direct unambiguous relationship, despite occasionally-weak aggregate-level associations observed in post-hoc analysis. This is incredibly important for the study of gerrymandering more broadly, since the assumption that odd shapes cause bias has long lacked data to support the claim, and this casts doubt on the claim using new robust empirical methods.  

Validity Study

This final component of the project interviewed practitioners, commissioners, and staff members of the nonpartisan/independent redistricting commissions in Washington and Arizona. The interviews

  • identified (un)successful structures or practices
  • examined the meaning, utility, and realism of common measures of partisan bias
  • investigated practitioner confidence in statistical models

In general, commissioners

  • supported many different measures of partisan symmetry and found other measures to be unrealistic (such as the efficiency gap). 
  • were resistant to considering turnout, the total number of votes cast in a district election, to assess partisan bias. 
  • were skeptical of whether votes cast for candidates were ever "wasted," and whether votes cast for "hopeless" losers were truly equal to votes cast for strong winners. 
  • thought WA or AZ could split in the popular vote for Democrats & Republicans at 50%, the conceptual reference position for most partisan symmetry analyses. 
  • tended to have high confidence in statistical estimates of partisan bias, but did not use them in the 2010 redistricting cycle. 

This qualitative interview work is important, as it begins to examine the conceptual validity of measures that are debated about in the academic literature. It explores whether individuals who are actually responsible for drawing districts have confidence in academic concepts, theories, and measurements. 

Conclusion

Overall, NSF#1657689 supported a highly successful dissertation, with open and replicable software, data, and publications both during and after the term of the award.
